segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Thank you very much.
Good morning to everyone.
First of all, I apologise for not speaking any Polish. I
should know better, but that's it.
It's my pleasure to be here.
I'm going to talk about the IPv6 network
reconnaissance and I'm going to talk about the slide where, as I
was looking at other presentations and realise that
maybe some of you might not have not
been present at an IPv6 network reconnaissance presentation
before.
What I try to do with this talk is provide a very, very small
summary of some things related to IPv6 network reconnaissance
and how we can use it in the future and how we can use it
in the future to
improve the advances that we did in this field.
As a very brief introduction about myself, I work as a
security researcher and consultant at SI6 networks.
I do quite a bit of work at the IETF, which is the standards
organisation for
internet protocols, meaning that I write protocol standards.
I also work as a security engineer and
consultant for different organisations on the topic of
communications protocol security.
So that's my website. There's the quote that she referred to
and also some of these documents.
A very small introduction, obviously you know what network
reconnaissance is about, so essentially whether you are
maliciously attacking a site or whether you want to do a pen
attack or whether you want to do an IPv4 attack, you need to
learn about a network. In order to be able to do that, you need
to learn information about a network. That's very, very
well-known stuff.
Now, what's different when it comes to IPv6 is that some of
the techniques that you typically apply to an IPv4
network, they cannot really be applied to IPv4. The most
simple example of all of that is the typical host scanning
technique.
So if you have a lot of IPv6 addresses, you have a lot of
address scans in IPv4, where you have like a slash 24 prefix,
for example, and you go through the whole address space for
that network, obviously that's doable when it comes to IPv4,
because the address space is very reduced, it's very small.
You only need to try less than 300 addresses in a typical
IPv4 network to be able to do that.
You can't do that with IPv6, because addresses are much,
much larger.
So in most cases you need to do something else.
So as a kind of like very brief summary of where things were
at when it comes to IPv6 network reconnaissance, essentially
we had smart host address scans. If you had never looked
at IPv6 before, you probably know that most IPv6 users
select their addresses with specific patterns, so with
IPv6 you have 128-bit addresses, of which 64 addresses are
the host ID part that you know from the IPv4 world.
In theory you might expect that the host ID part is random,
but in practice it's not.
In IPv6, the host ID part is random.
In IPv6, the host ID part is random, but in IPv6, when you
are doing random addresses, they follow specific patterns, and
we have produced tools like this one, Scan6, there are a few
others, not as complete, but there are, that whenever you
specify a network, what the tool tries to do is to try to
infer what's the pattern, the address pattern that is used at
that site, and only target those addresses.
In IPv6, you can do a lot of smart address scans with IPv4
address scans. In the IPv4 case, you just go through the
entire address space, because the address space is small, you
don't need to do a lot of smarts about that, but with IPv6,
at least you are able to reduce the search space, you will not
be able to do an address scan of a network.
So this is stuff that we already had, smart address scans.
I will provide a very brief summary about that.
And DNS reverse enumeration, you might have read about it, I
will provide a very brief summary about that.
And other techniques that are borrowed from the IPv4 world,
okay?
So what are the things that we will go through in this
presentation?
Some stuff having to do with using
IPv6 network reconnaissance, and
some stuff having to do with using IPv6 network
reconnaissance, and also one thing that I will try to
describe, like only a few things, time is reduced, is to
see if there are any insights that we gain, you know, from
using these techniques in practice.
So what does this mean?
Like, you know, when we were exploring different techniques
in practice, we had a lot of surprises in there.
Like, you know, when we were exploring different techniques
in practice, we had a lot of surprises in there.
In theory, they would work, but then when we started to play
with them in practice, well, we had a few small surprises in
there.
So what I will try to do in this presentation is provide some
comments about that.
First one is about leveraging search engines.
So what I will try to do in this presentation is provide some
comments about leveraging search engines.
So what I will try to do in this presentation is provide some
comments about leveraging search engines.
So first of all, let me try to introduce why I, you know,
started to work on this particular tool.
I was trying to do measurements about IPv6 deployment, like
different things.
Like, for example, coming up with a list of domains, like
for specific countries, could be Argentina, could be Poland,
could be any other country, could be any other country,
could be any other country.
So I was trying to figure out what was the percentage of
sites that had IPv6 deployed.
So, you know, it would be easy, just come up with a bunch of
domain names for a specific country, then for each of those
domain names, try to obtain, you know, the IPv6 addresses and
the IPv4 addresses.
If there are IPv6 addresses, that means that v6 is support,
otherwise it's not.
So I was trying to figure out, you know, what was the
percentage of sites that had IPv6 deployed.
So, you know, it was pretty obvious.
If you try to do those measurements for, like, global
sites, it's not that hard.
For example, you could download the Alexa top one million sites
and, you know, the list is there.
I also found that for some top-level domains, like, for
example, .se for Sweden and a few others, the registries,
you know, they were not available, so I had to come up
with, you know, a list.
For other zones, like Russia, for example, the list of domain
names was leaked. I don't know how, but it was up there.
But the thing was that for some of the zones that I wanted to
do the measurements, the list of domain names were not
available, so I had to come up with, you know, such a list.
In my particular case, it was kind of like more of a mass
scale or, you know, larger scale experiment.
For example, you wanted to obtain all of or as many domain
names as possible.
But obviously, it could, you know, you could just target,
you know, the same attack, if you want, for a specific domain
name if you were doing a pen test.
It's exactly the same thing.
So I, you know, I mean, it wasn't that hard to come up with
the idea that, you know, if you have search engines, that they
obviously index lots of domain names.
Rather than trying to find the domain names by yourself, you
could, you know, ask the search engines.
Most search engines obviously have, you know, support keywords
such as site where you can, you know, specify, like, a DNS zone.
And that means that the results are going to be restricted to,
you know, to the domain name that you are specifying there.
As I said before, it's useful for particularly for pen testing
a specific site.
And why?
I mean, and not that much if you want to download a whole zone.
But, you know, if you want to, you know,
you want to, you know, you want to, you know, you want to
specify a domain name, you can do that.
But, you know, if you are doing, like, if, for example, you
specify site.PL, well, the first couple of pages, you're going
to get, like, different results.
But after a while, they are all duplicates because they are all,
you know, part of the, they will all be webpages corresponding
to the, you know, to the same domain.
So, you know, I found that, you know,
I found that, you know, I found that, you know, I found that
there was a very obvious case, which is Google, okay?
And when I was trying to scrub the results, I found that they
were, like, obfuscated, not encrypted, but obfuscated.
Meaning that what you see on the webpage is not really what you
find on the HTML.
And I wasn't going, at least in principle, going to spend the
time, you know, trying to figure out what they were doing.
So, what I did after that was to find which other, you know,
search engines I could use.
I came up with this one, which I didn't know before, Teoma.
Apparently, they use, like, Google as a, you know, as the
motor, as the engine.
Problem being that, for example, this one will ban you after you
perform, like, let's say, high number or big number of queries.
It's usable if you are, for example, pen testing a specific
site, because with a few queries, you're going to obtain
most of the domain names.
But if you want to download, for example, all the domain names
for a, you know, top-level domain, say .pl, obviously, you
are not going to be able to do it.
And the thing is, with, for example, this particular search
engine, Teoma, they blacklist your IP address.
So, if you want to download, for example, all the domain names
for a, you know, top-level domain, say .pl, obviously, you
are not going to be able to do it.
And also, the thing is, with this particular search engine,
you are not going to be able to play with the IP address for one
or two days, meaning that at least you are able to change
often.
You're not going to be able to play for a long time.
There are other ones that kind of, like, require you to keep
state, meaning that it's not that you can't just, you know,
ask for a page with the results, but there's some kind of, like,
cookie in the page which you can read and then you have to
submit, not a big deal.
So, the other one, which is in the
next one, here, is Bing.
Bing, the nice thing about Bing is that it provides, at least
for this purpose, like, good results, and it never actually
bans you, okay?
So, you can keep sending queries, queries, queries, and,
you know, it never complains.
So, that's good for our purpose.
So, I implemented, essentially, like, a script that just
scraps, you know, the Bing results.
Now, obviously, the problem with, you know, just doing a
basic script is that if you want to target, you know, most
importantly, like, you know, like a top-level domain, say,
like, Navi.me, or something like that, well, and if there
are, like, you know, many web pages within that zone, you
know, after the, you know, four or five pages, you know,
after the fourth, tenth page, you start getting lots of
duplicates, and it's hard to, you know, to get new results.
So, my first try was to, you know, submit, to just add to a
query string, like, for example, random letters, A, B, C, that
leads to, you know, a different reordering of the results,
which was kind of like, okay, but not that good, and what I
tried after that is, essentially, use, you know,
Bing, but with a dictionary.
So, that's essentially what I, you know, ended up producing
for, essentially, liberation a search engine for potentially
downloading, like, let's say, a top-level domain, if you want.
What the tool does, for example, in this case, it will
produce a query string, like, specifying, in this case,
Navi.me, for, you know, the site, and then, you know, it
starts with each keyword in the dictionary.
So, it starts with the keyword in the dictionary that we are
specifying, and after a number of duplicates, it just changes
the keyword.
So, I mean, obviously, it's not perfect, but, for example, for
some top-level domains, say, I didn't try, I don't seem to
remember trying that with .pl, but, for example, with .ar for
Argentina, you know, running the tool for a few hours, I was
able to download about 100,000 domain names or something like
that, which was quite, you know, they were many more domains
than the ones that I already had for the measurements.
So, there is another technique that is interesting.
You can say that, I mean, it's just a different technique that
is complementary to the one that I described for, you know,
about the search engines.
You can discover some sites that you might be, you might not be
able to discover, you know, with a search engine, and vice versa.
So, one is not a replacement for the other.
So, this technique is about leveraging certificate
transparency, and as a very brief introduction, if you think
about certificates, you know, obviously, they are useful, for
example, for preventing money in the middle attacks, when, you
know, the certificates are, you know, working properly, but
obviously, as a system, let's say if you have a SSL client,
you are not able, for example, to tell whether a certificate
was issued by a rogue certificate authority.
Okay? So, obviously, if you know the
certificate, you know, you can detect money in the middle
attacks, but if there have been cases, I think I listed a few,
there were at least two cases, DG
Noter, that was issuing, you know, certificates after being
compromised, there was another case of Trustwave, in which
they were issuing subordinate root
certificates, because they wanted some of their certificates
to be able to, you know, sniff traffic.
These are examples that, you know, SSL by itself cannot just,
you know, prevent.
If there's a certificate authority that was compromised,
you know, there's nothing that, you know, this as a system can
do.
And that's where, you know, certificate
transparent framework comes into play.
So, essentially, you know, I think
that's all I have to say.
The other way to put things very
simple is to keep a centralised log of, you know, how the
certificates are generated, so
essentially, it's possible, you know, for owners of domain names
to essentially figure out whether, you know, somebody has
issued a certificate for a domain name that they own.
So, essentially, you know, you can
keep a centralised log of that, so that there's something wrong
going on with, you know, certificates that they are
trying to employ.
When it comes to the components of, you know, the
certificate transparent framework, there are essentially
three parts. The first one is the certificate logs, so
essentially, when, you know, certificates are issued,
they have to be monitored.
So, essentially, you monitor all the
certificate logs, and then the last element in this framework,
you have the auditors, which could be like a piece of
software, for example, in your browser, which tries to make
sense out of these components.
But the most important part, we don't, I mean, this was an
introduction for the stuff that we will see afterwards, but the
idea, or what's important from our
point of view, is that you have a log,
a centralized log, where you keep a log of all the
certificates that have been issued, okay?
So, there's like a kind of, you know, there's a log that you
can actually search, where, you know, you will find, in theory,
all the, you know, certificates that, you know, have been
issued.
So, what did I do, is I produced, oh, this is a website,
one of the logs where you can actually search for the
certificates, but I produced a tool that, you know,
searches, is able to search the logs and, you know, provide the
results in a more scriptable output.
Essentially, you run the tool like that, you specify a zone,
and, for example, like in this case, I just specified the zone
LACNIC.net, could be any example.
But the idea is that you specify a zone, and as a result,
you get all of those lists of domain names that, you know,
were present in the, you know, in the logs that I referred to
before.
One thing that you have to keep in mind, you might wonder,
well, what are the domain names that I might be able to find,
let's say, here versus, you know, the search engines?
Well, first of all, the domain names that you are able to find
here are domain names for which a certificate has been issued.
So if there is some site that doesn't use, for example, SSL
at all, you know, you will not be able to do anything with it.
On the other hand, there might be certificates that are not
being employed, for example, for the web or for FTP, for
example, so in those cases, you wouldn't be able to find those
domain names, you know, with a search engine, but you would be
able to find those domain names using the certificate
transparency framework, okay?
So, again, with the certificate transparency framework, you are
able to find domain names for which certificates have been
issued, whereas on the other hand, when it comes, obviously,
to search engines, obviously, you will only be able to find
domain names for which, you know, some form of content has
been indexed.
They are complementary, so if you try to, you know, if you
use the tool, you know, trying to find domain names for a
specific zone with a search engine, you will see the set of
domain names that you find, then you compare with the set of
domain names that you find with this tool, and usually, you
know, they are not exactly the same results, so that's why I'm
saying that they are complementary.
What else?
So these are two, you know, tools that I
produced recently, and when I was, you know, studying this
topic, I, you know, one of the, you know, same main topics when
it comes to IPv6 network reconnaissance, which is
actually one of the few topics that is specific to IPv6, is the
patterns that IPv6 addresses follow in the real world.
I was mentioning before that, you know, if you look, let's
say, if you download the top 1 million sites of Alexa, and you
obtain all the corresponding IPv6 addresses and you try to,
you know, analyse those addresses, you will find that
those addresses follow patterns, specific patterns.
Years ago, when we were, you know, working on this topic, we
produced statistics about, you know, what are the patterns
that these addresses were following, at least for the,
you know, Alexa's top 1 million sites.
But the thing is that since we did that study, there are some
things that changed.
Specifically, I think that we have done this study maybe five
years ago, and in the last, what was it, like two, three years,
we published these two new RFCs, 7217 and 8064, which
essentially changed the way in which IPv6 addresses are
generated.
If you have never seen how an IPv6 address looks like, well,
you have the first example on the left-hand side, obviously
looks ugly, because they are, oops, 15 minutes, we are fine.
In which, obviously, it's a 128-bit long address, written
in hexadecimal form, and what I highlighted over there is that
what you see in blue is to some extent or another the MAC
address of the underlying network interface card.
So if you did an if config of this system, you would see that
it has the MAC address of the underlying network interface
card.
So if you did an if config of this system, you would see that
it has the MAC address 26EC99 and blah, blah, blah, what you
see in blue.
I mean, there are minor details, but that's kind of like the
idea.
What we did, I mean, there's a bunch of security and privacy
issues with including MAC addresses in the interface ID.
Among others, obviously, when you move from one network to
another, the MAC address stays the same, so that means that
obviously, if you generate IPv6 addresses by including a MAC
address in the interface ID, that also means that the
addresses will follow patterns, obviously, because, for
example, if you purchase, like, all of the boxes in your
network from the same vendor, well, the MAC addresses are
usually going to be consecutive, so they will follow patterns,
meaning that it's going to be easier for an attacker to
actually scan the whole network. So we replaced that.
That was the traditional scheme to generate IPv6 addresses,
which we changed, like, say, one, two, three years ago.
It was updated in the standards and then it was actually
updated in, you know, popular specifications.
If you look at, let's say, recent versions of Fedora,
Ubuntu, FreeBSD, macOS, they all employ this new scheme.
They randomise the IPv6 addresses.
So what's on the left-hand side was changed to what's on the
right-hand side, which essentially means the interface
ID, the low order 64 bits, were replaced by a random number.
So the question here was, you know, since we produced this
change in the standard and since implementations were
updated in response to that, we were trying or we redid
measurements that we did a few years ago to see if, you know,
we could see any changes in the real world.
Sometimes, you know, what you write on paper, you know,
doesn't reflect into, you know, changes in the real world.
So these are the measurements that we produced.
We did them with three different data sets. I mean, there's much
more that you can measure. This is just a summary, obviously,
because time is constrained.
What we did for this particular slide was to actually look at
the IPv6 domain names.
So for this particular slide, we
obtained the top 1 million sites list from Alexa and we obtained
the query records for each of those domain names.
Obviously, for many of them, IPv6 is not supported, but for
those domain names that support IPv6, well, these are the
results.
So the IPv6 domain names, let's say the biggest, the larger
part of the pie, those are addresses that embed IPv4
addresses. What does that mean?
Like, well, people configuring the addresses of websites, what
they do is they manually configure the IPv6 interface ID
to be the same as the corresponding IPv4 address.
So let's say if that network interface card has a 10 point
blah, blah, blah IPv4 address, they include the IPv4 address
in the interface ID.
You might wonder why they do that.
Let's say my guess is that it makes it easy for them to
remember the IPv6 address of the server.
So if you do remember that the IPv4 address is blah, blah,
blah, then it's easy to come up with the IPv6 address.
So let's say my guess is that it makes it easy for them to
remember the IPv6 address of the server.
So that's just the IPv6 prefix and then the IPv4 address.
Then there is this part of the chart over here, this smaller
part, which is about randomised addresses.
That's a much larger set of addresses than what we had
measured years ago.
That's a much larger set of addresses than what we had
measured years ago.
So the changes we did in the specs actually reflected into
changes in the real world.
Now, the part that I couldn't, let's say, come up with some
sort of analysis that made sense is that if you look at the
very small part in blue up there, those are addresses that
embed the MAC address.
If you look at the very small part in blue up there, those
are addresses that embed the MAC address.
If you look at the very small part in blue up there, those
are addresses that embed the same percentage of addresses
including the MAC address.
That's the part of the puzzle, if you want, that I couldn't
solve.
What I expected is that all the addresses or most of the
addresses that at the time were including the MAC addresses
now would migrate to addresses that are randomised.
That's the part of the puzzle, if you look at the very small
part in blue up there, that I couldn't, let's say, come up
with some analysis that made sense.
Maybe they are there. Maybe they are new systems.
But it's not that we replace all of those addresses that
contain the MAC address to randomised ones.
These are similar measurements but with a different data set.
In the same way that these guys from Alexa, they publish the
list of popular sites.
And there is another company, yet another company called
Majestic, I don't know what they do, but they also publish
their list of popular domain names which are useful if you
want to, I mean, they are supposed to be the domain names
that you find in these domain name sets.
They are supposed to contain, like, you know, popular domain
names, okay? But, you know, the results are similar.
So, most of the addresses embed an IPv4 address in the
interface ID and you have, like, a larger set than before of
randomised interface identifiers.
Conclusions here, when it comes to, you know, address scanning
from the perspective of the attacker, is that you have
between 15 and 20 per cent of randomised addresses in the
interface.
So, you have between 15 and 20 per cent of randomised
addresses, those are addresses that, you know, with the tools
that we have right now for address scans, you wouldn't be
able to discover in principle.
Why? Because, you know, they are addresses that are randomised
in a 64-bit address space, meaning that you will not be
able to find, they don't follow any patterns and, you know,
they don't follow any patterns.
So, that's one of the reasons.
I also mentioned before that, you know, there was an
increased number of randomised addresses, but the addresses
that included the MAC addresses are still there in the chart.
Some comments on DNS reverse mappings.
I, you know, for the sake of the following slides, I will
give you a quick summary.
In the same way that you can map a domain name into, let's
say, an IP address, like when you, you know, type a domain
name in your browser, it's possible to map an IP address,
whether IPv4 or IPv6, into a domain name.
Maybe one of the most obvious examples for that is that when
you, for example, are running traceroute, you get the list of
IPv4 or IPv6 addresses that correspond to routers, and
along with them, you obtain the corresponding domain names.
In order to be able to obtain domain names, those domain
names, you have to employ the DNS reverse mappings.
In the case of IPv6, it's the IPv6.
ARPA zone that is employed for those reverse mappings.
In the case of IPv6, you have the IPv6 address into, you
know, a string of hexadecimal digits, and if you map that
string into a PTR record, you will be able to obtain a
corresponding domain name.
Now, if you look at the graphic that I have over there, you
know, it should be possible, it's actually possible to walk
that zone as a tree instead of, you know, going brute force.
Essentially, you start at the top of the tree, and then for
each nibble, you try to obtain a domain name, and there are
two possible responses that you can obtain.
One is NX domain, and the other one is no error.
If you obtain NX domain, that means that there's nothing in
that part of the tree.
If you obtain no error, that means that you should keep
exploring in that part of the tree.
This is an example of using this technique.
So, for example, this is a tool that was produced by Mark
Oyzer.
If you see at the top of the slide, essentially we run the
tool and we specify an IPv6 prefix, and what the tool does,
it walks the DNS reverse mappings tree, trying to find
PTR records for the corresponding v6 addresses.
This is not another scan.
It's actually walking, you know, the DNS tree for reverse
mappings.
So, what's interesting about this technique is that you can
employ the technique for discovering, let's say, new
addresses, but there are some, you know, lessons that we
learned when, you know, we were employing this in practice.
I have a very concrete example. I have left this tool running
for, I think it was a slash 32, and after a couple of weeks, I
go to that virtual machine, and I find that I have like a few
gigabytes log in 30 of results.
So, I say, okay, well, that was quite nice.
I'm going to, you know, maybe I found lots of systems.
Now, when I actually take a deeper look into the log, I see
that there are tons and tons of domain names like this.
What does it mean?
Well, it means that there are certain sites that rather than
specifying mappings for specific addresses, they just use wild
cards, meaning that you think that you are discovering a lot
of addresses, but you're just hitting wild cards.
That happens for a lot of sites.
Deutsche Telekom comes to mind, but there are a few others.
This is like Yahoo, if I remember correctly. Yeah.
There's another one, another lesson that, you know, I learned
by, you know, running this with a lot of sites, which is that
you can specify a prefix of any length when you run this tool,
like a slash 32, and it should be okay.
Now, in practice, what happens is that if you try to do, if
you try to use these techniques, for example, for prefixes that
are shorter than a slash 48, well, somehow, your queries are
filtered somewhere.
So, what we learned was that it's more effective, more
reliable if you use slash 48s or smaller prefixes.
So, that means that, for example, if you want to scan a
slash 32, what you should probably do is, you know, split
the slash 32 into smaller prefixes, like, for example,
slash 48s.
Closing this, this is just a very brief summary.
Many of these techniques are split in a, you know, in a
number of different tools, meaning that you run the DNS
enumeration tool and a bunch of other tools, but it's hard
to put all the tools, it's hard to put all of the results
together.
So, I produce a very, extremely preliminary tool for putting
the, you know, the results together, which essentially
what it does, without getting into details, the tool, for
example, uses a, you specify, for example, a domain name, the
tool comes up with a list of domain names, then you get
prefixes, and you go through all the techniques, and eventually
the results converge to something.
The, I mean, being a football fan and being here where we are
playing the World Cup, we named this tool after our, let's say,
only hope in winning the World Cup, Messi.
If you are a football fan, we wish we hadn't, you know,
named this tool Maradona, but for us, Maradona is up here, so
that would be like a flawless tool, which is not this case.
We like Messi, but not as much as Maradona.
Acknowledgements.
I know that I was painful.
I was at the conference, and I was actually chasing other
